ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded the live lecture

Weekly sections with a TA.
Note: The live virtual lecture was very interactive.  The professor encouraged us to interrupt him with questions, which made lecture feel more similar to a seminar.
Live virtual lecture, but also recorded.
Live lecture
Section
Sections and review sessions
Recorded lecture, recorded section, live virtual office hours
Weekly Section
Virtual discussion sections
There were also discussion sections.
Section was mix of virtual discussion/lecture

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Simplex algorithm, Walrasian equilibrium, Monetary/credit card equilibrium, leverage cycle

Learned much deeper math behind everything from the micro to financial theory. Additionally we covered many theories for the causes of macro disasters, such as leveraging creating economic crises. Additionally this is probably the only class at Yale which talks about how money can change many things beyond just interest rate and how credit cards lead to inflation.

Very cool class

This course greatly increased my theoretical understanding of fundamental economic theorems and types of equilibrium.  Of any economics course that I have taken, this course most successfully paired mathematical rigor with real-world applications.
General equilibrium theory, going through a bunch of different economic models. Talked about mortgages and credit cards. I learned how to solve these models.

The first half: Arrow-Debreu general equilibrium (intermediate micro on steroids. The same concepts though much more mathematically rigorous, including proofs). 
The second half: whatever Geanakoplos felt like teaching (monetary equilibrium, credit card equilibrium, the leverage cycle, prepaying mortgages). Some of these were interesting, but they are all things Geanakoplos has come up with and some of them there's almost no consensus in the economics community.
Linear programming, nonlinear programming, Walrasian equilibrium, monetary equilibrium, leverage cycle, binomial trees
I learned how to compare mathematical models to reality in order to better understand whether they have validity. I also learned how to apply constrained optimization to different types of problems.
Mathematical understanding of how economy works including a theory about the crisis I've never come across before.
Great course
Mathematical rigor, principles of general equilibrium

An introduction to general equilibrium theory, with a focus on computation of equilibria and some discussion in lecture of important theorems and their proofs. Transferable utility economies, Walrasian equilibria, one- and two-period monetary equilibria, credit card economies, and the Leverage Cycle. The latter half of the course gets at some pretty frontier stuff drawing from John G's own research (albeit in highly simplified form).

When studying for/taking the final for this course, I realized I had learned barely anything. The class is a mere extension of concepts from intermediate micro/macro but both lacks economic intuition and mathematical learning. Maybe it would have been different if in person. The professor spends time on his own research which, while cool, was sometimes difficult to follow. At the beginning, the first concept was really interesting. Throughout the course, we could have discussed economic agents and their decisions as opposed to hand-wavey proofs that barely scratched the surface, but only got any of this insight in discussion section or with other students.
I definitely got more used to solving general equilibrium models, but the course felt so erratic I find it difficult to have a good sense of exactly what I learned.
Lots and lots of economics, really interesting stuff especially in the second half.
Further discussion of equilibrium theory and modeling various forms of economies.

Linear programming (simplex algorithm), convex-concave optimization (Kuhn-Tucker), different types of general equilibrium such as exchange-economy equilibrium, Walrasian equilibrium, monetary equilibrium, credit-card equilibrium. A lot of the content beyond classical general equilibrium features Professor Geanakoplos's own work prominently. After equilibrium, coverage of the leverage cycle, mortgage payment/pricing, a little bit of financial pricing in general. You'll also have to learn some of the basics of Python for computation. Makes matrix operations slightly more tolerable.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Excellent lectures, helpful problem sets

The problem sets and tests were properly sized and interesting. Not too challenging but not easy. The online notes were great. Only issue was lecturing. Don't know if because of iPad but lectures were hard to follow and writing was frequently illegible.

While the professor is kind enough to give us the notes, it is very math notation heavy, and I had to spend so much time deciphering what it means. It would be much easier if we can have a simple example in class, or we worked through the problem together, rather than being presented it on the notes. The few times we did do that, I grasped the concept immediately, but whenever the problem/model was just on the class notes and we just talked about them without thoroughly and step-by-step going through it, I was confused.
Dedicate more time to more mathematical concepts.

The strength of this course was Professor Geanakoplos' focus on his own work. They are interesting models, that I may never have had a chance to learn, and certainly not learn as deeply, if it were not for this class. The personal anecdotes, and Geanakoplos' thoughts about the specificities of the models, taught me to think about general equilibrium in new ways. Geanakoplos' models made me think about what changes could enhance Walrasian Equilibrium. Unfortunately, these other great parts of the course made the discussion of Walrasian Equilibrium quite short. In the end some of the discussion of Walrasian Equilibrium felt like a repeat of Micro Theory, except tatonnement and stability were new to me. I do not know what could be done to fix this, however, because each other part of the course feels crucial. Most importantly however, and although as a Math major I am probably in the minority when I say this, I took this class to get a proof based view of economics. As a result the first half of the course amazing. Although Geanakoplos did a great job to explain the ideas behind the proofs in the second half of the course, it would have been nice to do more proofs in this course.
learned A LOT. the material could be very dense. Personally, I think class could benefit from showing practical applications then diving into theory vs. other way around.

Handwriting can be neater
Maybe more time to release pre-lecture notes

Strengths: relevant, interesting material, great TAs, meaningful class, John G is really funny and caring lecturer

Weaknesses: the lectures were sometimes confusing, hard to follow, especially the pure math ones
This course could be better organized.

The strengths are that the material itself could potentially be interesting or engaging. When trying to study, researching other institutions version of the course lent great insight. However, these potential strengths were grossly overshadowed by the lack of total learning in the end. When exams came, many students scrambled through notes and recorded lectures to find answers as opposed to really understanding the material in the course, because of the incredibly poor structure.

The class felt very erratic and all over the place. We jumped from topic to topic very abruptly, and it often felt like we were just learning models because Professor Geanakoplos came up with them. The caliber of the student in the class was very high, however, which made the class engaging and fun.
Not much to be improved upon, thought there was a good balance of everything.
Phenomenal teacher and TAs.

Strengths: Prof. Geanakoplos knows what he's talking about, and a lot of the material is based on his research. He is also very good about encouraging questions to make sure people understand what is going on. The course definitely ties together theory and actual events pretty well, and shows how and why certain things happen in the economy. This includes phenomenon such as inflation, trade, leverage, price booms/busts, and certain aspects of mortgage pricing. The problem sets are pretty computation-heavy, even though they could definitely be more proof-based. 
Weaknesses: Lecture could be hard to follow at times, and the notes weren't always easy to comprehend. Slightly more proof-based work may have deepened understanding; there were very few problems that lay between completely theoretical and completely computational.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recorded lecture was super nice. Gives flexibility with timezones. Honestly can't think of ways to improve as COVID-19 pandemic has negatively shifted the quality of life for all.
Professor Geanakoplos did a great job making sure that students were engaged and following the material. We primarily had a "cameras on" classroom which made the semester more enjoyable.
The course was pretty-well adapted to Covid-19, with lectures and sections that were both recorded, Piazza, etc.

Geanakoplos always engaged us, which at times was nerve racking, but created a great teaching environment where student input was valued. Despite being online, it did not even feel like a lecture, but more like a high school classroom where discussion follows each main point of the lecture. I liked when Geanakoplos talked over his notes as it made lecture go faster, was easier to read, and did not go too fast or take away from the learning as he talks about his notes very well.
This applies to any class: the amount of work required in the class was far too much to be handled online.
Recorded office hours and recorded section were great. I think it generally worked well. It would be great to have pre-recorded mini lectures in addition to the live lectures.

Discussion section always went well and Ahyan is an incredible TF who tries to understand each student. The professor did not know how to use any technology and oftentimes, his written notes were entirely incomprehensible and illegible. Perhaps in the future, instructors can be given a virtual instruction session on how to use remote learning tools like a tablet.
Section was very effective and helpful for this class. I thought learning from Professor Geanakoplos over Zoom was difficult, especially when he would just go over PDFs of papers he had published.

It was good to post typed-up notes before lecture that were also easily accessible as references. The course would have benefited from a better setup for writing during lecture, i.e. an iPad for annotating lecture notes rather than a mouse cursor.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely would recommend. Very engaging lecturer. Interesting models.

If you are good at math and interested in finance, this is a great class for you. Very interesting with a brilliant teacher. We get to learn about credit cards, default, loans, and money in a way certainly not covered in any other econ course. Funny stories, hand-waivey proofs. Don't come expecting the rigor of a math course or the conjectures of econ.

I would definitely recommend this to any student interested in economic theory.  Professor Geanakoplos is excellent at explaining important theorems and discoveries that are applied in intermediate micro and macro with limited explanations.

Absolutely not if you are a normal person. You gotta speak and breathe math in order to have a smooth sailing through this course. That being said, if you want to do econ research and you are good at math, definitely take the class because the Professor is so smart and definitely interesting to listen to.

If you are a math-econ major, you basically have to take the class. Anyone else thinking about the class would probably be interested in finance or something. Please find something more interesting to do with your life. 

I would definitely not recommend the class. The lectures were Geanakoplos reading aloud from his lecture notes, with tons of skipping around and rushing through sections. No one ever had any clue what was going on. For two classes he actually wrote the math out on a tablet and people seemed to be following better but then he decided that was too hard so he was just going to go back to talking about his lecture notes in front of the class. Everyone was confused and too scared to ask questions, and even though he claimed that he loved questions, everyone was intimidated to do so because he often acted like we were idiots if we didn't immediately understand his convoluted explanations. I learned everything in section but the time in section was only less than half than was in lecture (and in a fast-paced course), so there was no way to get through everything during section. He completely rushed through the interesting half of the class on Arrow-Debreu because he claimed we had seen most of it before (but not with this much mathematical rigor!) so that he could show off his new ideas and try to convince us of things that we didn't really understand because his explanations were incomprehensible. 

The problem sets were graded on completion and there was no feedback provided. Since the answers were not always just numerical but could involve proofs or explanations, this was very unhelpful, especially given that the solution sets were often incomplete, littered with errors, or contradicted information provided in class or section. Also, halfway through the semester, Geanakoplos started posting them on Thursday due Tuesday, and I know that almost no one would have started them before the weekend anyways, but I felt it was inconsiderate to not give us the full week.

The exams were absurd. Midterm was a 24 hour take home designed to take 3 hours, but it took almost everyone at least double that. It was a random Wednesday in the middle of the semester, so if you had anything else going on you were screwed. The final was even worse. We had basically three days, and it was supposed to take 6 hours. I spent probably 18 hours on it, and I know students who spent more. Friends in the class said it was the worst three days of their lives. The problems were never-ending with ~10 subsections. The subsections were also often incomprehensible and it would be almost impossible to tell if there was a question buried in them and you had to spend time figuring out what he was actually asking (example: "Can you see how you could imagine a continuum of homeowners lying anywhere between completely rational, and completely inert (never prepay)?").  It also had a problem on something we barely covered and two unnecessarily long problems on stuff from before the midterm that we had already been tested on so there was no point in including them in the final. 

The class also claimed to teach Python but we learned next to nothing and in the second half of the semester, Geanakoplos would show examples with incomprehensible Excel spreadsheets and then expect us to be able to replicate whatever he was doing on problem sets and the final.
This course is a must take. The material feels too important for one semester. If only there were one semester focused on general equilibrium and a second semester focusing on Geanakoplos' research.
Absolutely, the next iteration of the class will most likely be even better. You learn so much from an amazing professor who shows you how he thinks when creating models of the economy.
Yes
Yes, if the material is interesting to you, if you have sufficient mathematical background, and if John G is teaching.
Yes, it builds character.

If you don't know what concave/convex functions are or haven't taken at least lin alg and multi, probably stay away. Otherwise, I'd recommend if you're at all interested in economic theory. It was a lot more interesting than I anticipated.

For econ/math, this course is essentially required. The econ/math community does get closer with this course but as a whole, major improvements are necessary so students are both challenged and learning. The challenges in this course came from the disorganization, not actually the material itself. If it had been the other way around, the class would have been far more fulfilling. This was by far the least engaging and worst course I have taken.
Probably not, unless you have to take it for Econ/Math.
Yes, great to learn a bit more about some of the more challenging concepts in economics.

Yes, The professor was amazing and the top in his field. He was also very engaged in the course and clearly cared about student learning. We also learned a lot, material that I hope to use in my future job.

Yes. I felt like I developed a better understanding and intuition for economics, aand saw how events in the real word could be explained by certain models/theories. The portions of the course on monetary equilibrium and leverage felt like particularly relevant topics for understanding the real economy.
